MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Temporary Contract.

Qst.Quest: if a person employed on a temporary contract for more than two years in that position is then made permanent.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. B. Ahern) Bertie Ahern
Speaker.P: Employees' entitlements are determined under collective and individual agreements on the one hand and statutory labour law on the other.

The conditions under which a person is employed are governed primarily by the terms of the agreement or contract entered into by the parties. It is these rather than the passage of any particular period of time which determine whether the employment is to be regarded as temporary or permanent. While some agreements may provide for permanent status after a particular period of satisfactory service, this is entirely a matter for negotiation and agreement between the parties in drawing up the contract of employment.

In relation to statutory labour law there are no clear cut provisions which respond directly to the question which the Deputy has put. The employee's entitlements under a range of protective enactments, including the Minimum Notice and Terms of Employment Act, 1973, the Unfair Dismissals Act, 1977, and the Redundancy Payments Acts, 1967 to 1984, are determined by reference to the eligibility requirements specified in those Acts and not by the description of the individual's employment status. These eligibility requirements generally include provisions relating to hours of work and duration of service.

MainHeading.P: Under the Minimum Notice and Terms of Employment Act, 1973, employees who work at least 18 hours per week and who have at least 13 weeks' continuous service with the same employer are generally entitled to a minimum period of notice on termination of employment. The Unfair Dismissals Act, 1977, applies in general to employees who work at least 18 hours per week and have at least a year's continuous service with the same employer. Employees with two years' continuous service, or more, who are normally expected to work at least 18 hours per week are covered by the Redundancy Payments Acts, 1967 to 1984.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Qst.Quest: the proportion of the Irish population living in poverty in accordance with the United States measures of poverty, the level of which is a cash income less than three times the cost of a nutritionally adequate but minimum diet, which in the United States in 1983 was $10,000.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: There is no measure of poverty levels in Ireland based on a nutritionally adequate diet corresponding to the poverty line used in the United States.

Issues relating to the measurement of poverty were addressed by the Economic and Social Research Institute in their report, Poverty Income and Welfare in Ireland, and also in their working paper on Concepts of Poverty and the Poverty Line. The ESRI did not adopt the US approach but stated that no entirely satisfactory and convincing method of drawing a unique poverty line is available. The ESRI consider that poverty can only be meaningfully interpreted, in a country such as Ireland, in the context of the standard of living and ordinary living patterns in that particular society. They, therefore, concentrated their efforts on measuring poverty by means of a set of relative poverty lines. I intend to continue to support their very valuable work in this area.

Qst.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Qst.Quest: if he will review the case of a person (details supplied) in Dublin 12 who paid full social welfare contributions for a number of years; and if the person concerned is entitled to a pension or a reduced pension.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: The person concerned will reach qualifying age for retirement pension in 1994 or for old age pension in 1995. Based on insurance /PRSI contributions definitively recorded on his behalf, he is expected to satisfy the qualifying conditions for receipt of either of these contributory pensions even if he gets no further contributions reckonable for those pensions.

In order to qualify for an old age contributory pension it is necessary to have a minimum average of at least 20 contributions recorded from 1953 or from date of entry into insurable employment, whichever is the later, up to the last contribution year before reaching pension age. Entitlement to retirement pension is subject to an average of not less than 24 contributions.

In this case the records of my Department show that a total of 1,011 reckonable contributions have been recorded up to 5 April 1989 — the most recent year for which records are available. This represents a yearly average of 24 contributions for the period 1953 to 1995 — the year he reaches pension age. This average would result in a pension at the current weekly rate of £54.90 for a single person or £92.90 for a married pensioner whose spouse is under 66 years of age. The 1,011 contributions recorded exclude certain contributions since 1984-85.

The contribution record of the person concerned is at present under investigation for 1984-85 and subsequent years. The results of these investigations may result in prospective entitlement to a higher rate of pension. When investigations are completed he will be notified of the outcome without delay.

I must stress that the information contained in this reply is not a formal decision on pension entitlement. It is not possible to give a formal decision so far in advance of pension age. The reply provides an indication of entitlement based on existing social welfare legislation.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Qst.Quest: if he accepts that there is a staffing crisis in the supplementary welfare system especially in areas 4 and 5 of the Eastern Health Board; if his attention has been drawn to the fact that frequently community welfare officers on leave are not replaced thereby leaving people without community welfare services; that many of the staff in the areas concerned are under stress; if he will approve a minimum of 12 extra community welfare officers in order to prevent a major crisis; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: My Department's personnel policy for 1990 allows health agencies flexibility to make permanent or temporary appointments within the parameters of their financial allocation and an overall establishment ceiling. Accordingly, the Eastern Health Board have authority to revise their staffing mix in accordance with service priorities while adhering to overall financial and staffing targets.

In line with this policy the Eastern Health Board are currently reviewing their staffing requirements in the supplementary welfare service and as an interim measure, arrangements have been made to place some additional staff in area 5 where the situation is particularly pressing.

It is inaccurate to suggest that community welfare officers on leave are frequently not replaced. As a general rule, replacements are provided for all planned leave and for most unplanned absences. In a small number of instances it is not possible to provide a replacement where the absence occurs without notice but even in such cases, a replacement is always provided not later than the third day of absence.

In recognition of the stress factor inherent in the role of the supplementary welfare service, the Eastern Health Board includes stress management as a component of its training programme for community welfare officers.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Recognition of Teachers from Northern Ireland.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Qst.Quest: if she will give details of her policy on the recognition of second level teachers from Northern Ireland, who have not passed the aptitude test in Irish, for appointment to posts in second level schools in the State to perform responsibilities other than the teaching of Irish.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: A teacher who does not have an acceptable qualification in the Irish language may not be appointed to an authorised permanent whole-time position in a community, comprehensive or vocational school. Where for an authorised permanent whole-time position there is among the candidates, otherwise properly qualified, no candidate possessing an acceptable qualification in Irish, a temporary whole-time or part-time appointment may be made for one year pending the acquisition of the Irish language qualification.

A teacher who lacks the necessary qualification in Irish may be appointed to a post in a secondary school, on a temporary basis, for not more than one year, pending passing the relevant examination before the end of that school year. Unless the teacher obtains the appropiate qualification, he/she is removed from the payroll until such time as the qualification in Irish is acquired. These regulations apply to all teachers, including those from Northern Ireland, and I have no plans at present to change them.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - EC Support for Education.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Qst.Quest: if she favours an amendment to Article 128 of the Treaty of Rome to include explicit provision for EC support for education in member states.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: Article 128 of the Treaty of Rome states that, “the Council shall, acting on a proposal from the Commission and after consulting the Economic and Social Committee, lay down general principles for implementing a common vocational training policy capable of contributing to the harmonious development both of the national economies and of the common market”.

Article 128 refers only to vocational training. However, Article 235 of the same Treaty states that, “if action by the Community should prove necessary to attain, in the course of the operation of the common market, one of the objectives of the Community and this Treaty has not provided the necessary powers, the Council shall, acting unanimously on a proposal from the Commission and after consulting the European Parliament, take the appropriate measures”. The provisions of Article 235 in conjunction with those of Article 128 have enabled the Community to co-operate in education policy matters up to the present in a reasonably satisfactory way.

However, the impetus towards political and economic union within the Community will undoubtedly have implications for education. Existing Treaty provisions may not be adequate to meet the aspirations and needs of the Community in the area of educational co-operation in the future.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Establishment of Teachers' Council.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I have set up a working party, representative of all the interested parties, to make recommendations on the establishment of a teachers' council including matters such as the composition, structure, functions and financing of such a body.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Schools Psychological Services Pilot Project.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Qst.Quest: if parents will be represented on the advisory committee on the pilot schools psychological service; and if not, the reason for their exclusion.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The National Parents' Council (Primary) will be invited to nominate a representative to the advisory committee on the pilot project for the establishment of a psychological service for primary schools. This has always been my intention.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - School Leavers Without Educational Qualifications.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Qst.Quest: if she has made an estimate of the prospective cost to the economy of the present level of school-leaving by those without any educational qualification.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: While the inter-departmental committee on the problems of early schools leavers referred to the 1986 Youth Employment Agency survey which showed that 88 per cent of the young long term unemployed had no school leaving certificate, and 51 per cent had no educational qualifications, no formal costings were undertaken of the effect of early school leaving on the economy.

Following the committee's report, the youthreach scheme providing two years' full-time vocational training for unqualified early school leavers was introduced jointly by the Departments of Education and Labour.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Assistance to Eastern European Countries.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Qst.Quest: if she has made any provision to provide training and educational assistance to east European countries similar to the Know How Fund initiated by the United Kingdom authorities.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The contribution by Ireland to the provision of training and educational assistance to Eastern European countries will be made in the context of Tempus (Trans-European Mobility Scheme for University Studies) and the European Training Foundation of the European Community. Both of these proposals are on the agenda of the General Affairs Council scheduled for 7-8 May 1990 under the Irish Presidency.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Qst.Quest: if she favours the introduction of a formalised system of teacher appraisal similar to that operating in some European countries.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The question of appraisal of primary teachers is one which the Primary Education Review Body is considering as part of their remit and I would not wish to pre-empt their recommendations on the matter by making a statement. I would, however, wish to draw attention to the fact that inspection of the work of teachers is provided for in Rule 161 of the Rules for National Schools and that the procedures therein were revised and up-dated by Circular No. 31/82.

In the case of post-primary teachers, it is a function of inspection to report on teachers performance in schools. Inspection procedures are formalised, in the case of vocational teachers, in my Department's Circular No. 43/85.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke

Qst.Quest: if she favours the introduction of team teaching in national schools; and if she will examine the feasibility of adopting the recently adopted Italian system of three teachers for every two classes.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: My Department examined the feasibility of introducing the team teaching system in national schools a number of years ago but considered that the co-operative teaching system was more suitable. This system is in operation in a number of schools at present.

Qst.Quest: if, in order to diminish the influence of third level entry requirements on the ordinary second level curriculum, she will introduce in Ireland a special university entry examination at the end of a special pre-university year such as operates in Spain.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I have no plans in this regard. The entry requirements for universities generally and the specific requirements for particular courses are matters for the appropriate authorities in the universities.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Schools' Computer Systems.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Qst.Quest: if all Irish schools which have computer systems, operate systems which are mutually compatible and compatible with the computers in use in her Department.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: All second level schools, with a few exceptions, have been grant-aided to purchase Apple IIe computers together with the appropriate software. The exceptions refer to schools which at the time of the grant schemes had already purchased BBC computers and which opted to have these upgraded.
Compatibility between computer systems as far as the Apple computer is concerned is thus guaranteed.

MainHeading.P: Communication between schools themselves and also between the schools and the Department is facilitated by the use of electronic mail. The mode for this facility is located at NITEC, The National Centre for Information Technology in Education, in Dublin City University. This facility is not dependent on the type of computer in use and some 100 schools are already on the system. It is understood that NITEC proposes to increase this to 160 schools shortly. Computers supplied to national schools by the Department of Education are mutually compatible. Specific arrangements for linkage with departmental computers have not been made.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Primary School Pupil Testing.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Qst.Quest: if all primary school children undergo the Drumcondra test of basic competence in reading, writing and arithmetic; and if not, the reason.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: While the Department encourage schools to use standardised testing, it is not compulsory for them to do so. The Department do not prescribe any particular tests.
As the Deputy will be aware, the remit of the Primary Curriculum Review Body covers the whole area of curriculum at the primary level and this area will be considered in the report.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Development Tests on Children.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Qst.Quest: if health tests on the developmental strength of children before entering school are furnished to the primary schools in a systematic way.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: Information on developmental tests conducted on children before entering school is not furnished to primary schools in a systematic way.
This information is strictly confidential and it is at the discretion of the parents whether they wish to provide the information to the school.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Recognition of Teaching Abroad.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Qst.Quest: the arrangements for the recognition for pension and increment purposes of service by Irish teachers in schools in other European countries; and if there are any EC or Council of Europe proposals to provide mutual recognition in these matters.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: In the case of primary and post-primary teachers incremental credit is allowed for approved teaching experience abroad up to a maximum of seven years, subject to a maximum of four years in respect of service given prior to 1 June 1979.
Such service is not reckonable for superannuation purposes.
There are no EC or Council of Europe proposals to provide mutual recognition in the matters referred to by the Deputy.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Progress of Pupils.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Qst.Quest: the extent, if any, to which teachers are required to keep written records of the progress of individual pupils.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: Under the terms of circular 7/68, the principal teachers of national schools are obliged to ensure that a school record card is completed in respect of each pupil in fifth and sixth standard, and that these cards are forwarded to the principal teachers of the schools to which these pupils transfer.

Under the parents' report scheme introduced in 1969 school reports on children are provided to parents at the end of the school year in respect of children in second and higher standards. These reports provide an assessment of a pupil's general progress throughout the year and the standard of attainment reached by them in the various subjects of the school curriculum.

MainHeading.P: As part of their normal duties, post-primary teachers would be expected to chart the progress of their pupils. Where course work features as an element of assessment, the teachers concerned are required to keep comprehensive records.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Qst.Quest: if her Department collect timetable information from all second level schools; the frequency with which this information must be provided; the use made of the information; and the cost of the collection of it.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: Second level schools are required to forward completed timetable forms to my Department in September each year.

These timetable forms, which give details of the assignment of staff and the allocation of time to the various subjects on the curriculum together with the days of school closure, are considered essential for a number of reasons, including the determination of whether conditions for payment of salary are fulfilled, the consideration of staffing questions and the planning of programmes of inspection.
Procedures for dealing with this information vary from school to school and, therefore, it is not possible to give the cost of collecting this information.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Maternity Leave.

Qst.Quest: if she will clarify the situation in relation to paid maternity leave for teachers arising out of a recent test case, whereby the maternity leave occurs during a holiday period; whether her Department intend to pay holiday leave to teachers in such circumstances; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The present position is that under the scheme of maternity leave for teachers, permanent teachers are entitled to 14 consecutive weeks' paid maternity leave.

MainHeading.P: The scheme also provides that a teachers may take up to four consecutive weeks' additional unpaid maternity leave immediately after her paid maternity leave. As an alternative to this the scheme allows a teacher the option of taking extended unpaid maternity leave up to the end of the school year in which the birth occurs.
My Department have obtained legal advice in the matter referred to by the Deputy and it is under consideration at present.

Qst.Quest: the number of secondary school teachers at present on a career break for (a) four years, (b) three years, (c) two years and (d) one year.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: A total of 761 secondary teachers have taken career breaks for the 1989-90 school year.
My Department do not keep records in a format which would make the additional information requested readily available.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Re-engagement of Former State Employees.

Qst.Quest: if, since 1989, any former State employees have been engaged, either permanently or on contract, by her Department; and if so, if she will give (i) their names, (ii) the terms of their employment or contract, (iii) the salary being paid to them and (iv) the pension, if any, payable to them from the State.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: Since 1 January 1989, eight former State employees have taken up permanent employment in my Department. Six of the eight were formerly employed by Teagasc and the other two were employed at the Carysfort Primary Teacher Training College. The redevelopment to my Department was handled by the Civil Service Commission which recertified the officers as divisional inspector (1), assistant principal officers (5), executive officer (1) and clerical officer (1). The terms of the officers' employment are similar to those which apply to all officials serving in those particular grades. Likewise, the salary scales which govern the salaries of these officers are the same scales which apply to all divisional inspectors, standard scale APOs, EOs and COs in the Civil Service. No pension is payable at this stage.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke

Qst.Quest: if the Government will ratify the European Convention on the protection of those persons availing of schoolarships for study abroad.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The European Agreement on continued payment of scholarships to students studying abroad was opened for signature on 12 December 1969. It has been signed to date by Cyprus, France, the Federal Republic of Germany, Iceland, Luxembourg, The Netherlands, Spain, the United Kingdom and Austria.

Student mobility has become increasingly important in recent years as witnessed for example, by the high participation in the ERASMUS programme. I have arranged that legal advice will be sought at an early date so that the necessary arrangements can be made in order that Ireland can sign and ratify the agreement.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke

The school authorities have applied to my Department for grant aid for the provision of palisade fencing. My Department have under consideration the local architect's recommendation on the tenders received for the works and a decision will be conveyed to the school authorities at an early date.
I am not in a position, at this point, to say exactly when the works will commence.

Qst.Quest: if she has any plans to reduce the length of incremental scales for teachers; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke

Accordingly, it would not be appropriate for me to make any comment on the matter.

Qst.Quest: the regulations governing the overflight of helicopters in a metropolitan area such as Dublin, which is densely populated; and if single-engined helicopters are allowed to overfly the city of Dublin as a matter of routine.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan)
Speaker.P: The Air Navigation (Rules of the Air) Order, 1973 (S.I. No. 22 of 1973) requires that all helicopter flights are conducted without hazard to persons or property and at a height which would permit a helicopter, in the event of an emergency occurring, to alight without hazard to persons or property.
